Table 1: Comparison of FedAvg and STEM with different FL algorithms for various choices of the minibatch sizes (b)𝑏(b) and the number of per node local updates between two rounds of communication (I)𝐼(I). 
⋄ ν∈[0,1]𝜈01\nu\in[0,1] trades off b𝑏b and I𝐼I; ν=1𝜈1\nu=1 (resp. ν=0𝜈0\nu=0) uses multiple (resp. 𝒪​(1)𝒪1\mathcal{O}(1)) local updates and 𝒪​(1)𝒪1\mathcal{O}(1) (resp. multiple) samples. Fed STEM  and Minibatch STEM are two variants of the proposed STEM.
‡The data heterogeneity assumption is weaker than Assumption 2 (please see [9] for details).
†Requires bounded Hessian dissimilarity to model data heterogeneity across WNs.
∗Guarantees for Minibatch STEM  with I=1𝐼1I=1 and SCAFFOLD are independent of the data heterogeneity.

references: Recently, the works [17, 18] proposed to utilize hybrid momentum gradient estimators [7, 8]. The MIME algorithm [17] matched the optimal sample complexity (under certain smoothness assumptions) of 𝒪​(ϵ−3/2)𝒪superscriptitalic-ϵ32\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{-3/2}) of the centralized non-convex stochastic optimization algorithms [5, 6, 7, 8]. Similarly, Fed-GLOMO [18] achieved the same sample complexity while employing compression to further reduce communication. Both MIME and Fed-GLOMO required 𝒪​(ϵ−3/2)𝒪superscriptitalic-ϵ32\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{-3/2}) communication rounds to achieve an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-stationary solution. Please see Table 1 for a summary of the above discussion.

Theorem 3.1 suggests that when I𝐼I and b𝑏b are selected appropriately, then STEM achieves 𝒪~​(ϵ−3/2)~𝒪superscriptitalic-ϵ32\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(\epsilon^{-3/2}) and 𝒪~​(ϵ−1)~𝒪superscriptitalic-ϵ1\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(\epsilon^{-1}) sample and communication complexities. Taking them separately, these complexity bounds are the best achievable by the existing FL algorithms (upto logarithmic factors regardless of sample or batch Lipschitz smooth assumption) [35]; see Table 1. We note that the 𝒪​(ϵ−3/2)𝒪superscriptitalic-ϵ32\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{-3/2}) complexity is the best possible that can be achieved by centralized SGD with the sample Lipschitz gradient assumption; see [5]. On the other hand, the 𝒪​(ϵ−1)𝒪superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{-1}) complexity bound is also likely to be the optimal, since in [9] the authors showed that even when the local steps use a class of (deterministic) first-order algorithms, 𝒪​(ϵ−1)𝒪superscriptitalic-ϵ1\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{-1}) is the best achievable communication complexity. The only difference is that [9] does not explicitly assume the intra-node variance bound (i.e., the second relation in Assumption 2-(ii)). We leave the precise characterization of the communication lower bound with intra-node variance as future work. ∎

Note that the requirement on T𝑇T being lower bounded is only relevant for theoretical purposes, a similar requirement was also imposed in [14] to prove convergence.
Again, the parameter ν∈[0,1]𝜈01
u\in[0,1] in the statement of Theorem 3.2 balances I𝐼I and b𝑏b at each WN while maintaining state-of-the-art sample and communication complexities; please see Table 1 for a comparison of those bounds with existing FedAvg bounds.
For ν=1𝜈1
u=1, FedAvg (cf. Theorem 3.2) reduces to FedAvg proposed in [12, 14] and for ν=0𝜈0
u=0, the algorithm can be viewed as a large batch FedAvg with constant local updates [15, 16]. Note that similar to STEM, it is known that for I=1𝐼1I=1, the Minibatch SGD’s performance is independent of the heterogeneity parameter, ζ𝜁\zeta [13]. We also point out that if Algorithm 1 uses Nesterov’s or Polyak’s momentum [14] at local WNs instead of the recursive momentum estimator we get the same guarantees as in Theorem 3.2.
